questions.text: 40 year old lady presents with a 3x2 cm breast carcinoma in the left breast. Lump is attached to the pectoralis major muscle with skin ulceration and there are fixed & matted axillary lymph nodes in the left axilla & mobile axillary LN in the right axilla, which also show the presence of tumor.  What is the stage?
questions.solution:
TNM stage is T4bN2M1

  • Tumor: Size of 3*2 – maximum dimension i.e. 3 is considered and with pectoralis involved with skin ulcerations over the breast  hence it comes under T4b (Tumor size 2-5cm in greatest dimension).
  • Nodes: Ipsilateral fixed or matted axillary lymph nodes come under N2A.
  • Metastasis: Contralateral lymph node involvement (Here mass is on left breast and axillary lymph nodes in right side are involved) is considered as M1.

Points to remember:

  • In tumor size assessment, greatest dimension is considered. For example if a mass is 6*2cm in size, 6cm is taken into account and it comes under T3 (>5cm).
  • Skin involvement doesn’t include nipple retraction.
  • Supraclavicular lymph node involvement indicates N3c.
  • Enlargement of any contralateral lymph node is considered as distant metastasis.
  • If 2 masses are present in same breast, staging is according to bigger mass.
  • If mass in both breasts – separate staging for both the masses.

questions.text: Diamond triad of thyrotoxicosis include all except?
questions.solution:

questions.text: Which one of the following is the true statement with regards to neck trauma?

choices.text: Zone 1 extends from angle of mandible to base of skull.
Zone 2 injuries are the least common.
Majority of the neck injuries can be managed conservatively.
Only hemodynamically unstable injuries require CT neck evaluation

questions.solution:
Less than 15% of penetrating injuries to the neck require formal neck exploration. Majority can be managed conservatively.

Penetrating inju­ries are characterized by anatomic location and the neck has been divided into 3 zones.

  • Zone I extends from the thoracic inlet to the cricoid cartilage and contains large vascular structures as well as the trachea and esophagus.(Option A)
  • Zone II extends from the cricoid cartilage to the angle of the mandible. Zone II is the most accessible surgi­cally and contains the carotid and vertebral arteries, jugular veins, and structures of the aerodigestive tract.
  • Zone III extends from the angle of the mandible and the base of the skull. Structures within zone III include blood vessels that are difficult to expose surgically.

Other options:

Option B: Zone 2 is the most common site of injury followed by zones 1 and 3.

Option D: Hemodynamically unstable patients are taken for exploratory operative management immediately. CT neck/chest scan should be done in all patients with hemodynamically stable, symptomatic zone 1, zone 2 and zone 3 injuries along with angiography,esophagogram and bronchoscopy according to injured structures. Additionally, zone 3 injuries may require angioembolisation. All gunshot wounds to the neck should also undergo CT before exploration.

questions.text: Which one of the following statements is NOT true regarding damage control surgery?

choices.text: It is indicated in trauma patients who show features of hypothermia, acidosis and coagulopathy
In the first phase of damage control surgery, correction of anatomy is given more importance than correction of physiology
In the first phase, the aim is to control hemorrhage and prevent contamination
In the re-look laparotomy, correction of anatomy is given more importance

questions.solution:
In the first phase of damage control surgery, correction of physiology is given more importance than correction of anatomy.

  • Damage control surgery refers to the concept of limiting the initial operative interventions, in the unstable trauma patient, to those maneuvers that are imme­diately lifesaving (e.g., control of surgical hemorrhage, control of continued fecal contamination).
  • More time-consuming, definitive reconstructive efforts i.e. correction of anatomy are delayed until later, after resuscitation, when the patient is more stable and can tolerate such reconstruc­tive efforts.
  • Physiologic rationale for damage control surgery: As a metabolic consequences of extensive blood loss and blood and fluid replacement, these patients develop progressive hypothermia, acidosis, and coagulopathy (the so-called lethal triad), which can be corrected only when the patient can be brought to the intensive care unit with appropriate warming, fluid resuscitation, and other critical care interventions performed.

Components of Damage Control or Hemostatic Resuscitation

  • Permissive hypotension until definitive surgical control
  • Minimize crystalloid use
  • Initial use of 5% hypertonic saline
  • Early use of blood products (PRBCs, FFP, platelets, cryoprecipitates)
  • Consider drugs to treat coagulopathy (rFVIIa, prothrombin concentrate, TXA)

questions.text: A patient is undergoing an elective laparoscopic appendicectomy and the bowel has been prepared. During surgery, the small bowel gets perforated and there is minor spillage of some contents into the peritoneal cavity. What class of surgical wound is this?
questions.solution:
The wound would be classified as clean-contaminated wound as the alimentary tract is entered under controlled conditions (minor spillage with prepared bowel) without gross contamination. 

Surgical Wound Classifications as Defined by ACS NSQIP: 

Class I - Clean Wound:  Uninfected operative wounds in which no inflammation is encountered and the respiratory, alimentary, genital, and uninfected urinary tracts are not entered. Eg. Non-traumatic elective surgery and coronary bypass. 

Class II - Clean / Contaminated: Operative wounds in which the respiratory, alimentary, genital, or urinary tract is entered under controlled conditions and without unusual contamination. Eg. Elective cholecystectomy, appendicectomy, elective colon surgery after bowel preparation.

Class III - Contaminated: Open, fresh, accidental wounds; operations with major breaks in sterile technique or gross spillage from the gastrointestinal tract; and incisions in which acute, nonpurulent inflammation is encountered. Eg. Emergency cholecystectomy, appendicectomy, emergency colon surgery in unprepared bowel.

Class IV - Dirty: Old traumatic wounds with retained devitalized tissue and wounds that involve existing clinical infection or perforated viscera. Eg. Abscess, peritonitis (gross fecal contamination)

questions.text: All of the following are true about accelerated partial breast irradiation (APBI) except:

choices.text: APBI is delivered in an abbreviated fashion and a lower total dose than standard course of whole breast radiation
Suitable patients for APBI include women older than or equal to 50  years
Suitable patients for APBI include patients whose tumor margins are greater than equal to 3mm
Suitable patients for APBI include those with multifocal disease

questions.solution:
Patients suitable for APBI include women 50 years of age or older with a unifocal, T1/Tis, ER-positive tumor with no lymphovascular invasion, and margins of at least 3 mm.

Accelerated Partial Breast Irradiation (APBI) is done for selected patients with DCIS and early-stage breast cancer. Principle: This involves limiting the radiation to the area of the primary tumor bed with a margin of normal tissue because majority of recurrences after breast conservation occur in or adjacent to the tumor bed. It is delivered in an abbreviated fashion (twice daily for 5 days) and at a lower total dose compared with the standard course of 5 to 6 weeks of radiation (50 Gray with or without a boost) in the case of whole breast irradiation

American Society for Radiation Oncology Guidelines for Accelerated Partial Breast Irradiation divides patients into 3 groups - Suitable, Cautionary, and Unsuitable based on risk factors such as age, margins, T stage, DCIS, ER status, multicentricity, multifocality, lymphovascular invasion etc.

questions.text: What is the ideal time to give prophylactic antibiotic?
questions.solution:
• The antimicrobial agent should be started within 60 min before surgical incision (120 min for vancomycin or fluoroquinolones).
  • Although single-dose prophylaxis is usually sufficient, the duration of prophylaxis for all procedures should be <24 hr.
  • If an agent with a short half-life is used (e.g., cefazolin, cefoxitin), it should be readministered if the procedure duration exceeds the recommended redosing interval (from the time of initiation of the preoperative dose).
  • Readministration may also be warranted if prolonged or excessive bleeding occurs or if there are other factors that may shorten the half-life of the prophylactic agent (e.g., extensive burns).
  • Readministration may not be warranted in patients in whom the half-life of the agent may be prolonged (e.g., patients with renal insufficiency or renal failure).

questions.text:
Phlegmasia cerulea dolens is best described as:

DVT - Deep vein thrombosis

choices.text: Extensive DVT of the leg veins associated with cyanosis

questions.solution:
Phlegmasia cerulea dolens(PCD) is extensive DVT of the leg veins associated with cyanosis. In this condition, the collateral veins are also thrombosed.

Phlegmasia is a term that has been used to describe extreme cases of lower extremity DVT, which may progress to critical limb ischemia and potentially limb loss. The underlying pathologic condition of phlegmasia dolens is acute extensive VTE occluding the venous outflow of an extremity. The iliofemoral segment is almost always involved and occluded in the lower extremities. In 20%-40% of cases, phlegmasia has been associated with malignancy. However, other risk factors for VTE include hypercoagulable disorders, venous insufficiency, surgery,  pregnancy, the use of oral contraceptives, and prolonged immobilization.

In PCD, there is near-total occlusion of the major deep venous system and most of the microvascular collateral veins of the extremity, causing severe venous congestion. It is characterized by pain and pitting edema. The most pathognomonic feature is the presence of cyanosis. As cyanosis and worsening venous congestion progress, patients develop necrosis and venous gangrene.

Supportive measures should be performed immediately and are considered first-line. The extremity should be elevated to an angle greater than 60 degrees above the level of the heart to prevent venous stasis and to increase venous return through remaining patent channels. Definitive management involves anticoagulation, catheter-directed thrombolysis, and thrombectomy.

Note:

In phlegmasia alba dolens, the thrombosis involves major deep venous channels of the extremity and spares the collateral veins. The venous drainage is decreased but still present; the lack of cyanosis differentiates this entity from phlegmesia cerulea dolens. Phlegmasia alba dolens also called as milk leg.

questions.text: Which of the following is used for wound infection grading?
questions.solution:
Southampton wound grading system is used to score the severity of wound site infection.

Southampton wound grading system:

  • Grade 0 - Normal healing
  • Grade I - Normal healing with different grades of erythema
  • Grade II - Erythema with other signs of inflammation at different parts of the wound.
  • Grade III - Clear or serosanguinous discharge at different sites
  • Grade IV - Pus discharge

Other options:

Option A: American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA)  grading is used in pre-anesthetic checkups to assess a patient's physical health and fitness for anesthesia and surgery.

Option B: Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome (SIRS) is a set of clinical criteria used to identify and monitor critically ill patients with high-grade burns, severe trauma, and other major surgeries.

Option D: Acute Physiology and Chronic Health Evaluation II (APACHE II)  is a scoring system used to assess the severity and predict the outcome of pancreatitis.

Cleft lip, soft palate and hard palate repaired in three separate sittings at 5-6 months, 1 year and 2 years
Cleft lip and  palate is ideally repaired in two sittings at 5-6 months and 15-18 months
Cleft lip and palate is ideally repaired in two sittings at 5-6 months and 5-6 years

questions.text: Which is the most common feeding regime-related complication following total parenteral nutrition (TPN)?
questions.solution:
Hyperglycaemia is found in up to 50% of parenteral nutrition patients. Important predictors are insulin resistance or diabetes mellitus, severity of the underlying illness, concomitant steroid therapy, and the amount of glucose provided.

Complications of parenteral nutrition

Related to nutrient deficiency

  • Hypoglycaemia, hypocalcaemia
  • Hypophosphataemia & hypomagnesaemia (refeeding syndrome)
  • Chronic deficiency syndromes (essential fatty acids, zinc, mineral and trace elements)

Related to overfeeding

  • Excess glucose: hyperglycaemia, hyperosmolar dehydration, hepatic steatosis, hypercapnia, increased sympathetic activity, fluid retention, electrolyte abnormalities
  • Excess fat: hypercholesterolaemia and formation of lipoprotein X, hypertriglyceridaemia, hypersensitivity reactions
  • Excess amino acids: hyperchloraemic metabolic acidosis, hypercalcaemia, aminoacidaemia, uraemia

Related to sepsis

  • Catheter-related sepsis
  • Possible increased predisposition to systemic sepsis

Related to line

  • On insertion: pneumothorax, damage to adjacent artery, air embolism, thoracic duct damage, cardiac perforation or tamponade, pleural effusion, hydromediastinum
  • Long-term use: occlusion, venous thrombosis

questions.text: According to the NICE guidelines for head injury, which of the following statements is not true?

choices.text: Cervical spine immobilization should be done in all patients with suspected head injury
All patients with a GCS <8 require intubation
GCS <15 two hours after assessing the patient in the emergency room is an indication for CT
GCS in head injury patients should be monitored every hour for the first 2 hours

questions.solution:
GCS in head injury should be monitored every half an hour for the first 2 hours.

Other options:

Option A: Cervical spine immobilization should be done in all patients with a suspected head injury

Option B: All patients with a GCS <8 require intubation

Option C: For adults who have sustained a head injury and have any of the following risk factors, perform a CT head scan within 1 hour of the risk factor being identified:

  • GCS less than 13 on initial assessment in the emergency department
  • GCS less than 15 at 2 hours after the injury on assessment in the emergency department
  • Suspected open or depressed skull fracture
  • Any sign of basal skull fracture (Haemotympanum, ‘Panda’ eyes, CSF leakage from ear or nose, Battle’s sign)
  • Post-traumatic seizures
  • Focal neurological deficit
  • More than 1 episode of vomiting

Option D: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS of 15 should be as follows -

  • Half hourly for 2 hours
  • 1 hourly for the next 4 hours
  • 2 hourly thereafter

Related Pearl: NICE Guidelines for CT in Head Injury

National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) Guidelines for Computed Tomography (CT) in Head Injury

Indications for CT imaging within 1 hour of the following risk factors being identified:

  • Glasgow Coma Score (GCS) <12 on initial assessment
  • GCS <15 at 2 hours after injury on assessment in an emergency department
  • Focal neurological deficit
  • Suspected open, depressed, or basal skull fracture
  • More than one episode of vomiting
  • Post-traumatic seizure

Indications for CT imaging within 8 hours:

  • Age >65 years
  • Bleeding or clotting disorders
  • Dangerous mechanism of injury (e.g., fall from a height of >1 meter/5 stairs, road traffic accident)
  • Retrograde amnesia >30 minutes

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: Which one of the following is NOT a feature of re-feeding syndrome?
questions.solution:
Refeeding syndrome is associated with hypophosphatemia, hypocalcemia, and hypomagnesemia.

Refeeding syndrome is a potentially lethal condition that can occur with rapid and excessive feeding of patients with severe underlying malnutrition due to starvation, alcoholism, delayed nutritional support, anorexia nervosa, or massive weight loss in obese patients.

It can occur with both enteral and parenteral nutrition but is more common with the latter. Electrolyte abnormalities can result in cardiac failure and dysrhythmias, respiratory failure, neu­rologic disturbances, and renal and hepatic dysfunction.


Prevention: Caloric replenishment should be instituted slowly and increased gradually over the first week. Vital signs, fluid balance, and electrolytes should be closely monitored and any deficits should be corrected as they evolve.

Thiamine should be administered before the initiation of feeding. Since thiamine is an important cofactor for the metabolism of glucose and the conversion of lactate to pyruvate. When the body is replenished following starvation as in refeeding syndrome, thiamine requirements increase, and lactate levels can accumulate.

Thiamine deficiency leads to neurological manifestations(dry beri-beri) such as Wernicke's encephalopathy(memory impairment, ophthalmoplegia, ataxia) and Korsakoff syndrome (anterograde/retrograde amnesia, confabulation). Thiamine deficiency has also been implicated in cardiac tissue dysfunction due to insufficient ATP production(wet beri-beri).

questions.text: The instrument which uses the ultrasonic energy to cut the tissues is?
questions.solution:
The harmonic scalpel is a surgical instrument used to simultaneously cut and cauterize tissue. Ultrasonic energy is famously used in Harmonic scalpel where ultrasonic energy is converted to mechanical energy at the active blade.

In monopolar surgery, electrical current goes through the patient to complete the current cycle, while in bipolar surgery, the current only goes through the tissue in between the two electrodes of the instrument.

LigaSure vessel sealing system is a bipolar apparatus for sealing vascular tissue. It applies a high coaptive pressure during the generation of tissue temperature under 1000°C, hydrogen cross-links are first ruptured and then renatured, resulting in a vascular seal that has high tensile strength. Melted collagen and elastin in the vessels forms a permanent plastic like seal. It provides secure seal of blood vessels measured up to 7 mm diameter.

Thunderbeat STM (Olympus), has combined both modalities in a single device. By simultaneously using ultrasonic vibration and bipolar diathermy, this device is able to seal and divide arteries and veins up to 7 mm in diameter.

There is also a ‘seal only’ mode activated by a separate button, which activates bipolar diathermy only.

questions.text: Which of the following is the dominant cytokine in the pathogenesis of SIRS (systemic inflammatory response syndrome)?
questions.solution:
SIRS is the result of proinflammatory cytokines related to tissue malperfusion or injury.

The dominant cytokines implicated in this process include interleukin (IL)-1, IL-6, and tissue necrosis factor (TNF).

Other mediators include nitric oxide, inducible macrophage-type nitric oxide synthase, and prostaglandin I2.

Old guidelines:

SIRS  

Two or more of following criteria are met:Temperature ≥38°C (100.4°F) or ≤36°C(96.8°F)

Heart rate ≥90 beats per minute

Respiratory rate ≥20 breaths per minute or

Paco2 ≤32 mmHg or mechanical ventilation

White blood cell count ≥12,000/μL or≤4000/μL or ≥10% band forms
Sepsis Identifiable source of infection + SIRS
Severe sepsis Sepsis + organ dysfunction

 New guidelines (2016):

  • Sepsis is defined as a life-threatening organ dysfunction caused by a dysregulated host response to infection.
  • The presence of SIRS criteria has been removed from the definition of sepsis.
  • In addition, the term ‘severe sepsis’ is removed from the guidelines.
  • Definition of septic shock: ‘sepsis with persistent hypotension requiring vasopressors to maintain MAP ≥65 mm Hg and having a serum lactate >2 mmol/L (18 mg/dL) despite adequate volume resuscitation’.
  • The ‘quickSOFA’ (qSOFA) score: Patients outside the ICU are at risk of sepsis development if two or more of the following are abnormal:
    • Elevated respiratory rate ≥22 breaths per minute
    • Altered mental status (Glasgow Coma Scale score<15)
    • Systolic blood pressure of 100 mm Hg or less

questions.text: What is the fluid requirement of a 50 kg man with first degree burns to his left arm and leg, circumferential second degree burns to his right upper limb and third degree burns to his posterior torso and right lower limb. What is the rate of initial fluid resuscitation?

choices.text: 2.25L over 8 hours, followed by 2.25L over 16 hours
4.5 L over 8 hours, followed by 4.5 L over 16 hours
6 L over 8 hours, followed by 6 L over 16 hours
9 L over 8 hours, followed by 9 L over 16 hours

questions.solution:
Total volume of fluid needed is 4.5 litres of which 2.25L is given in first 8 hours and 2.25L is given in next 16 hours as indicated by 

Step 1: Calculating % of burns using rule of nines

  • This includes only 2nd and 3rd degree burns.
  • Right upper limb + right lower limb and posterior torso = 9 + 18 + 18 = 45%

STEP 2 : Calculating fluid using resucitation formula for thermal burns - 2ml x 50(kg) x 45(TBSA%) = 4.5 litres.

 

Note:

According to new ATLS 10th ed 2018 guidelines, the resuscitation formula for thermal burns is 2ml/kg/TBSA%. The fluid requirement during the initial 24 hours of treatment is 2 mL/kg of body weight for each percent of TBSA burned, given IV. Superficial (epidermal) burns are excluded from this calculation. One-half of the calculated fluid need is given in the first eight hours, and the remaining half is given over the subsequent 16 hours. The rate of infusion for IV resuscitation fluid should be as constant as possible; sharp decreases in infusion rates can lead to vascular collapse and an increase in edema

Related Pearl: Burns – Formulae for Fluid Calculation(Updated according to ATLS 10th edition 2018 guidelines)

Parkland’s formula gives the total fluid requirement for 24hours. Half of this volume is infused in the first 8 hours, and the remaining half is infused in the next 16 hours.

This formula is recommended for those who have sustained large deep partial-thickness or full-thickness burns that cover more than 20% of the TBSA in adults and more than 10% in children. 

Formulas provide a starting target rate; Subsequently, the amount of fluid provided should be adjusted based on urine output.

Evan’s formula is used for normal saline.

For the first 24 hours:

  • Amount of NS administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • Amount of colloid administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • 5% Dextrose administered= 2000 ml

After 24 hours, the amount of NS and colloid administered is half. 2000 ml of dextrose is maintained.

Muir and Barclay’s formula for colloids:

  • 1 portion of colloid = (weight in kgs x % TBSA)/2
  • 6 portions of colloid are administered over 36 hours

questions.text: In hemorrhage, larger arterioles vasoconstrict in response to the sympathetic nervous system. Which categories of shock are associated with vasodilation of larger arterioles?
questions.solution:
• The microvascular bed is innervated by the sympathetic nervous system and has a profound effect on the larger arterioles.
  • Following hemorrhage, larger arterioles vasoconstrict; however, in the setting of sepsis or neurogenic shock, these vessels vasodilate.
  • Additionally, a host of other vasoactive proteins, including vasopressin, Angiotensin II, and endothelin-1, also lead to vasoconstriction to limit perfusion to organs such as skin, skeletal muscle, kidneys, and the gastrointestinal (GI) tract to preserve perfusion of the myocardium and CNS.

All Follicular tumours carry worst prognosis BUT LINDSAY TUMOUR  (being follicular variant ) have better outcome.

questions.text: A 60-year old lady with a family history of breast cancer presents with blood-stained discharge from the nipple and sono-mammogram is normal. The next best investigation would be
questions.solution:

MRI is important for imaging breast in the following settings:

  • For assessing the multifocality and multicentricity in lobular carcinoma and to assess the extent of DCIS.
  • Best imaging modality in breasts of women with implants.

questions.text: Stemmer’s sign is due to?
questions.solution:
Stemmer’s sign is seen in grade II lymphedema (Brunner’s grading) and is due to subcutaneous fibrosis.

In case of lymphedema the contour of the ankle is lost through infilling of the submalleolar depressions, a ‘buffalo hump’ forms on the dorsum of the foot, the toes appear ‘square’ because of confinement of footwear and the skin on the dorsum of the toes (especially second toe) cannot be pinched because of subcutaneous fibrosis which is called Stemmer’s sign.

questions.text: Following is a marker of Paget’s disease of the mammary gland
questions.solution:
Paget’s disease of nipple is positive for CEA.

Paget’s disease is a superficial manifestation of an underlying breast carcinoma. It accounts for 1% or less of breast malignancies.

Clinical feature:

  • Presents as chronic, eczematous eruption of the nipple.
  • Progresses to an ulcerated, weeping lesion.
  • Usually is associated with extensive DCIS and may be associated with an invasive cancer.
  • A palpable mass may or may not be present

Diagnosis:

A nipple biopsy specimen will show a population of cells that are identical to the underlying DCIS cells (pagetoid features or pagetoid change). Paget cells are pathognomonic - Large, pale, vacuolated cells in the rete pegs of the epithelium.

Differential diagnosis:

  • Eczema
  • Contact dermatitis
  • Post­radiation dermatitis
  • Superficial spreading melanoma (Presence of S-100 antigen immunostaining in melanoma and carcinoembryonic antigen immunostaining in Paget’s disease).

Treatment:

Mastectomy with axillary staging or wide local excision of the nipple and areola to achieve clear margins, axillary staging, and radiation therapy.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presented with painless swelling as shown below. On examination, the swelling is soft, cystic, and transillumination positive. Which of the following is false regarding the likely diagnosis?

choices.text: The swelling arises from remnants of 2nd branchial cleft
The cystic swelling is lined by squamous epithelium
FNAC from the swelling may show cholesterol crystals

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of the branchial cyst. It lies superficial to the hypoglossal and glossopharyngeal nerves but deep to the posterior belly of the digastric.

The branchial cyst arises from the remnants of the 2nd branchial cleft. Normally, 2nd, 3rd, and 4th clefts disappear to form a smooth neck. A persistent second cleft is called cervical sinus (of His) which eventually gets sequestered to form a branchial cyst.

Swelling in the neck beneath the anterior border of the upper third of the sternomastoid muscle. It is smooth, soft, fluctuant, and often transilluminate. Even though congenital, it is seen in late adolescents and early 3rd decade.

Histologically, it is lined by squamous epithelium. The cyst wall shows plenty of lymphoid tissue. It may get infected to form an abscess.

FNAC shows cholesterol crystals which are derived from the sebaceous glands in the lining mucous membrane.

Treatment is by complete excision, which is best undertaken when the lesion is quiescent. It passes superficial to the hypoglossal and glossopharyngeal nerves but deep to the posterior belly of the digastric. These structures and the spinal accessory nerve must be positively identified to avoid damage.

Related Pearl: Brilliantly Transilluminating Swellings

  • Vaginal hydrocele
  • Epididymal cyst
  • Cystic hygroma
  • Ranula
  • Meningocele

questions.text: Most common malignant tumor of parotid is?
questions.solution: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is the most common malignant tumor of the parotid gland and can be divided into low-grade and high-grade tumors. High-grade lesions have a propensity for regional and distant metastases and corre­sponding shorter survival rates than low-grade mucoepidermoid carcinomas.

questions.text: Triple H therapy for subarachnoid hemorrhage consists of all except _______.
questions.solution:
Triple H therapy for subarachnoid hemorrhage does not include hypothermia.

The combination of induced hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution (triple-H therapy) is often utilized to prevent and treat cerebral vasospasm after aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH).

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: Components of myocutaneous flaps are
questions.solution:
Myocutaneous flap consists of skin, muscle and blood vessel.

Flaps are tissues that are transferred with a blood supply. They therefore have the advantage of bringing vascularity to the new area.

Types:

  • Random flaps: Three sides of a rectangle, bearing no specific relationship to where the blood supply enters; the length to breadth ratio is no more than 1.5:1.
  • Axial flaps: Much longer flaps, based on known blood vessels supplying the skin. It enables many long thin flaps to be safely moved across large distances.
  • Pedicled/islanded flaps: The axial blood supply of these flaps means that they can be swung round on a stalk or even fully ‘islanded’ so that the business end of the skin being transferred can have the pedicle buried.
  • Free flaps: The blood supply has been isolated, disconnected and then reconnected using microsurgery at the new site.
  • Composite flaps: Various tissues are transferred together, often skin with bone or muscle (osseocutaneous or myocutaneous flaps, respectively).
  • Perforator flaps: Subgroup of axial flaps in which tissues are isolated on small perforating vessels that run from more major blood vessels to supply the surface.

questions.text: A child, previously diagnosed with an endocrine tumor, presented with conjugate eye movements and myoclonus. Which of the following tumors must have led to this clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of conjugate eye movements and myoclonus indicates opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome (OMS). It is associated with neuroblastoma.

Opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome is rapid, conjugate eye nystagmus with involuntary spasms of the limbs, and is also called dancing eyes-dancing feet syndrome.

Causes:
  • When opsoclonus and myoclonus occur together, the cause is a tumor until proven otherwise.
  • In approximately 50 percent of affected children, neuroblastoma is responsible for the symptoms associated with OMS.
  • In other cases, the disorder has been designated ‘idiopathic’ or attributed to various mostly viral infections, such as Coxsackievirus B3 or St. Louis encephalitis virus

The main treatment for OMS is early and sufficient immunotherapy with the goal of gaining a durable complete neurological remission. If a tumor is present, surgical resection is standard. 

Neuroblastoma is a malignancy arising from the neuroblast cells in the adrenal medulla or sympathetic ganglia. It typically presents as an abdominal or paravertebral mass. The etiology is unknown, however, familial predisposition is associated with mutations in the ALK gene (anaplastic lymphoma kinase gene).

It is predominantly seen in children less than 5 years of age. Clinical features include mass effect due to the tumor (spinal cord compression, bowel obstruction) and metastatic disease. Raccoon eyes (periorbital ecchymoses) are seen in neuroblastoma due to orbital metastasis. In neonates, multiple cutaneous metastases cause deep blue discoloration of the skin called blueberry muffin baby. Children may present with fever, bone pains, and failure to thrive. Elevated blood pressure is seen due to increased levels of catecholamines in the blood. 

Histology shows small round blue cells with dark nuclei and scanty cytoplasm and Homer-Wright pseudorosettes. Urine vanillylmandelic acid (VMA) and homovanillic acid (HVA) are elevated. 

The mainstay of treatment is resection of the tumor and adjuvant chemotherapy. The drugs used from chemotherapy are carboplatin, cyclophosphamide, etoposide, and doxorubicin.

questions.text: Shock index is
questions.solution:
Shock Index is defined as heart rate divided by systolic BP.

It has been shown to be a better marker for assessing severity of shock than heart rate and BP alone.

It has utility not only in trauma patients but also in sepsis, obstetrics, myocardial infarction, stroke, and other acute critical illnesses.

questions.text: Which of the following are true regarding safe laparoscopic surgery in pregnancy?

choices.text: Patient should be positioned in the left lateral position
Open abdominal access (Hasson) is recommended versus direct puncture laparoscopy
Surgery should be performed during the second trimester if possible

questions.solution:
Laparoscopy in pregnancy:

  • In order not to damage the uterus or its blood supply, most surgeons feel that the open (Hasson) approach should be used in favor of direct puncture laparoscopy.
  • The patient should be positioned slightly on the left side to avoid compression of the vena cava by the uterus.
  • The operation should be performed during the second trimester of pregnancy if possible.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents with chronic constipation, headache, neuromas of the tongue, medullated corneal nerve fibres and a nodule of 2*2 cm in the left lobe of the thyroid. Which of the following syndromes does the patient have?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of MEN 2B syndrome. 

In MEN 2B, along with medullary thyroid cancer and pheochromocytoma, it is associated with other abnormalities such as mucosal neuromas, marfanoid habitus, medullated corneal nerve fibres, and megacolon. Parathyroid tumours are generally not seen here, in contrast to the MEN 2A type.

Multiple endocrine neoplasias (MEN) describe conditions with tumours involving two or more endocrine glands. There are four types - MEN 1-4. They have an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance and can also be sporadic. 

MEN type 2 comprises groups of disorders caused by gain-of-function mutations of the RET proto-oncogene at chromosomal locus 10q11.2. There are three variants:

  • MEN 2A, also known as MEN 2 (most common type)
  • MEN 2B, also known as MEN 3
  • MTC only

MEN 2A is also known as Sipple's syndrome. It is characterised by medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytomas, and parathyroid tumours. 

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

Related Pearl: MEN 1 Syndrome Features

Chromosome 11q13 / MEN1 gene

Also known as Wermer’s syndrome

Characteristic tumors seen in:

  • Parathyroid adenoma – 90 % - Most common overall
  • Entero pancreatic tumors - Most common functioning tumor is gastrinoma (most common site is duodenum)
  • Pituitary adenoma – Most common is prolactinoma
  • Mnemonic – Par Pan Pit – in decreasing order of frequency

Associated tumors are:

  • Angiofibroma
  • Collagenomas
  • Adrenal cortical tumors
  • Lipoma
  • Neuroendocrine tumors - gastric, thymic, lungs
  • Meningioma
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Carcinoid tumors, usually of the foregut

questions.text: Which one of the following statements regarding the management of breast cancer is NOT true?

choices.text: Mammaprint and Oncotype Dx are scores used in early breast cancer to predict the benefit of chemotherapy
Oncotype Dx is a 21 gene assay which can be used in ER positive and node-negative patients
Mammaprint is a 70 gene assay which can be used in ER, PR negative patients only
There is more data to support the use of Oncotype Dx

questions.solution:
Mammaprint is a multigene (70 gene) assay used for risk assessment in patients with ER-positive or ER-negative tumors.

Oncotype DX and Mammaprint are tumor genomic assays i.e. they assess expression of various genes in the given sample of breast tissue and thus help in determining the selection of patients for systemic treat­ment (e.g., chemotherapy, endocrine therapy) and predict the response of patients to these pharmacologic treatments. They also help in detecting the likelihood of recurrence.

Oncotype DX

  • 21 gene assay
  • Used for T1, and T2 tumors which are node-negative and ER-positive.
  • Used to assess whether patients with these tumors will benefit from chemotherapy.
  • The Oncotype DX test analyzes the activity of 21 genes and then calculates a recurrence score number between 0 and 100; the higher the score, the greater the risk of recurrence.
  • TAILORx trial and other trials support the use of Oncotype Dx

MammaPrint test

  • 70 gene assay
  • Used for T1, and T2 tumors which are node-negative but can either be ER-positive or negative
  • The MammaPrint test isn’t included in the NCCN and ASCO treatment guidelines.

Of the genomic tests used on breast cancer, the Oncotype DX test has the most thorough data supporting its use to make treatment decisions.

questions.text: All of the following are advantages of split skin graft except
questions.solution:
Split skin grafts are also known as Thiersch graft. It has more contraction compared to full thickness grafts. Hence they are not suitable for cosmetic purposes.

There are 2 types of contraction:

Primary contraction - the degree to which a graft shrinks in surface area after harvesting and before grafting.

Secondary contraction - the degree to which a graft shrinks during healing.

Advantages of split skin graft:

  • Large grafts can be harvested.
  • Donor site is reusable since part of dermis is left behind from which regeneration begins.
  • Uptake is good. Meshing can be done i.e. small splits are made in graft and any exudates collected can come out through this and this improves graft take up. Meshing also allows graft to expand from a ratio of anything from 1:1.5 to about 1:6.

questions.text: Amyloid stroma is characteristically seen in which carcinoma thyroid
questions.solution:
Histological section of medullary carcinoma thyroid shows cells resembling those in carcinoid tumors and shows characteristic amyloid stroma.

Option a: Papillary carcinoma thyroid shows papillary projections, Orphan-Annie eyed nuclei (pale empty nuclei) and psammoma bodies (microscopic calcified deposits).

Option b: Follicular carcinoma thyroid shows follicles which might be devoid of colloid sometimes.

Option d: Hurthle cell carcinoma is a variant of follicular neoplasm in which oxyphil (Hurthle, Askanazy) cells predominate histologically.

questions.solution:
The given image shows hypertrophic scars which have developed on possible sites of self-inflicted cuts. It has no genetic/familial predisposition.

Features Hypertrophic scar Keloid

Age Children Adolescents. Middle age

questions.solution:
Thymomas are usually the most frequently occurring neoplasm of the anterior mediastinum in adults.

questions.text: Identify the instrument
questions.solution:

  • Hold ribs during rib dissection, hold gauze for blunt dissection, hold resected bowel.
